SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving numerical expressions with rational numbers using the four operations.
Content: Which expression has the least value when x = 100?

SubTopics: Develop a uniform probability model by assigning equal probability to all outcomes, and use the model to determine probabilities of events.
Content: The cafeteria staff made sandwiches. Each sandwich had either rye or white bread, either ham or turkey, and either cheese or no cheese. The staff made an equal number of each type of sandwich. The sandwiches were placed on a tray. Without looking, Mary will choose a sandwich. What are the chances that Mary will get a sandwich with cheese?

SubTopics: Identify the unit rate (constant of proportionality) within two quantities in a proportional relationship using tables, graphs, equations, and verbal descriptions.
Content: A 5-lb bag of apples costs $4.50, and an 8-lb bag of the same type of apples costs $7.52. Greg found the unit price, which is the constant of proportionality between cost and weight, for each bag of apples. What is the difference in the unit prices?

SubTopics: Use measures of center and measures of variability for numerical data from random samples to draw comparative inferences about two populations.
Content: The scores that Joni and Sally received on their first seven assignments are shown in this table.
problems/NC18G7M/media/4a.jpg
Which statement is true?

A.Choice: Sally's median score is higher than Joni's median score.

B.Choice: Sally's median score is lower than Joni's median score.

C.Choice: Sally's median score is the same as Joni's median score.

D.Choice: The median scores cannot be determined.

SubTopics: Add, subtract, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.
Content: Which expression is equivalent to (2n + 6)/2?

SubTopics: Identify the unit rate (constant of proportionality) within two quantities in a proportional relationship using tables, graphs, equations, and verbal descriptions.
Content: Susan's weekly earnings were proportional to the number of hours she worked. This table shows the number of hours Susan worked and the amount she earned.
problems/NC18G7M/media/6a.jpg
How much money did Susan earn per hour?

SubTopics: Add, subtract, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.
Content: Which expression is equivalent to 3x – (2x + 4) + 5?

SubTopics: Create equations and graphs to represent proportional relationships.
Content: This table shows the relationship between x and y.
problems/NC18G7M/media/8a.jpg
Which equation models this relationship?

SubTopics: Add, subtract, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.
Content: Which expression is equivalent to 2(3 – x) – 12 + 4x?

SubTopics: Create equations and graphs to represent proportional relationships.
Content: Mr. Kelly pays $12,564 a year for rent. His rent is a constant amount each month. Which equation represents the amount he pays per month if m = months and c = total rent paid for the year?

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving numerical expressions with rational numbers using the four operations.
Content: A library has 12,500 fiction books and 19,000 nonfiction books.

:ibox:• Currently, 2/5 of the fiction books are checked out.
• Currently, 2/5 of the nonfiction books are checked out.
• Of the books checked out, 1/10 are due back this week.
How many books are due this week?

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving numerical expressions with rational numbers using the four operations.
Content: Kevin is paid $8.80 per hour. He worked 7 hours. He gave his mother 1/4 of his earnings. How much did Kevin have left?
(Note: Express the answer as dollars.cents.)

SubTopics: Use facts about supplementary, complementary, vertical, and adjacent angles in a multi-step problem to write and solve equations for an unknown angle in a figure.
Content: Square RSTU is inside trapezoid RSVU. What is the measure, in degrees, of angle VSR?
problems/NC18G7M/media/13a.jpg

SubTopics: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions to solve real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: Janet can make 4/5 of a necklace in 20 minutes. At this rate, how many necklaces, to the nearest tenth of a necklace, can Janet make in 1 hour?

SubTopics: Construct equations to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.
Content: Kyle bought x pencils. He paid $1.24, including tax, per pencil. He gave the cashier $20 and received $5.12 in change. How many pencils did Kyle purchase?

SubTopics: Use facts about supplementary, complementary, vertical, and adjacent angles in a multi-step problem to write and solve equations for an unknown angle in a figure.
Content: The angles in this diagram are complementary.
problems/NC18G7M/media/16a.jpg
What is the value of x?

SubTopics: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions to solve real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: A car used 1/64 of a gallon of gas to drive 1/4 of a mile. At this rate, how many miles can the car travel using 1 gallon of gas?

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving numerical expressions with rational numbers using the four operations.
Content: Craig earns the same amount of money each month. His telephone bill is 1/20 his monthly earnings, and he pays a total of $720 each year for his telephone service. How much does Craig earn each month, in dollars?

SubTopics: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions to solve real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: A recipe requires 1/4 cup of oil for every 2/3 cup of water. How much oil (in cups) is needed per cup of water?

SubTopics: Use facts about supplementary, complementary, vertical, and adjacent angles in a multi-step problem to write and solve equations for an unknown angle in a figure.
Content: In this figure, ST is a line.
problems/NC18G7M/media/20a.jpg
What is the value of x?

SubTopics: Use scale factors and unit rates in proportional relationships to solve ratio and percent problems.
Content: This table shows how much each type of meat costs at a local deli.
problems/NC18G7M/media/21a.jpg
A customer purchased 1/4 pound of ham, 1 1/2 pounds of turkey, 1 pound of roast beef, and 3/4 pound of bologna. APPROXIMATELY what will the customer pay for the purchase before sales tax?

SubTopics: Solve multi-step real-world and mathematical problems posed with rational numbers in algebraic expressions.
Content: Four friends each flipped a coin different numbers of times.

:ibox:• Alice got heads 75% of the time.
• Mary got heads 8 out of 10 times.
• Sarah got heads 17 out of 20 times.
• Ellen got heads 3/5 of the time.
Who had the greatest percentage of heads?

SubTopics: Understand area and circumference of a circle.
Content: Martin ordered a pizza with a 16-inch diameter. Ricky ordered a pizza with a 20-inch diameter. What is the APPROXIMATE difference in area of the two pizzas?

SubTopics: Generate multiple random samples (or simulated samples) of the same size to gauge the variation in estimates or predictions, and use this data to draw inferences about a population with an unknown characteristic of interest.
Content: A state representative took several random surveys of adults to find which place they visited most frequently. The average of all of the surveys is shown in this table.
problems/NC18G7M/media/24a.jpg
Based on the table, which conclusion can be made?

A.Choice: On average, 50% of the adults visited the zoo most frequently.

B.Choice: On average, 17% of the adults visited the park most frequently.

C.Choice: On average, 2 out of 25 adults visited the aquarium most frequently.

D.Choice: On average, 2 out of 10 adults visited the museum most frequently.

SubTopics: Use scale factors and unit rates in proportional relationships to solve ratio and percent problems.
Content: Tony bought a $48 sweatshirt and used a coupon for a 10% discount. Keith bought an identical sweatshirt at a different store for $42.95. Which statement is true?

A.Choice: Tony paid $0.25 less than Keith paid.

B.Choice: Tony paid $4.95 less than Keith paid.

C.Choice: Keith paid $0.25 less than Tony paid.

D.Choice: Keith paid $4.95 less than Tony paid.

SubTopics: Add, subtract, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.
Content: Which expression is equivalent to –(x/4 – 3/8)/2?

SubTopics: Use scale factors and unit rates in proportional relationships to solve ratio and percent problems.
Content: Erica saw a skateboard on sale for $59.95. The original price of the skateboard was $79.95. What is the APPROXIMATE percent discount on the skateboard?

SubTopics: For an event described in everyday language, identify the outcomes in the sample space which compose the event, when the sample space is represented using organized lists, tables, and tree diagrams.
Content: Jane wants to pick out an outfit for the school dance. She can choose from 3 pairs of pants, 5 shirts, and 2 pairs of shoes. How many different outfits does Jane have to choose from?

SubTopics: Solve problems involving scale drawings of geometric figures.
Content: This diagram is a scale drawing of a store.
problems/NC18G7M/media/29a.jpg
To the nearest 50 square feet, what is the area of the actual store?

SubTopics: Understand that, just as with simple events, the probability of a compound event is the fraction of outcomes in the sample space for which the compound event occurs.
Content: This spinner will be spun twice.
problems/NC18G7M/media/30a.jpg
What is the probability of spinning an odd number both times?

SubTopics: Construct inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.
Content: Which choice describes the value of m when –5(m + 1) ≤ 23?

SubTopics: Collect data to calculate the experimental probability of a chance event, observing its long-run relative frequency. Use this experimental probability to predict the approximate relative frequency.
Content: Paul has a spinner with 4 colors: green, yellow, blue, and orange. He spins the spinner 60 times and records each color it stops on. The results are shown in this table.
problems/NC18G7M/media/32a.jpg
Paul will spin the spinner an additional 450 times. How many times should he expect the spinner to stop on blue?

SubTopics: Understand area and circumference of a circle.
Content: Circle M has a radius of 7.0 cm. The shortest distance between P and Q on the circle is 7.3 cm.
problems/NC18G7M/media/33a.jpg
What is the APPROXIMATE area of the shaded portion of circle M?

SubTopics: Understand that statistics can be used to gain information about a population.
Content: Nicole wants to conduct a survey of the opinions of students at her middle school. Which survey sample would give her the most accurate results?

A.Choice: random students as they enter the school

SubTopics: Solve multi-step real-world and mathematical problems posed with rational numbers in algebraic expressions.
Content: A teacher divided the class into two groups of equal size.

:ibox:• 3/5 of the first group are right-handed.
• 80% of the second group are right-handed.
What fraction of the class is right-handed?

SubTopics: Understand that a proportion is a relationship of equality between ratios.
Content: This graph shows time and distance traveled for two objects.
problems/NC18G7M/media/36a.jpg
Which statement is true?

A.Choice: Object 2 travels 6/5 of a foot more per minute than Object 1.

B.Choice: Object 2 travels 5/6 of a foot more per minute than Object 1.

C.Choice: Object 1 travels 6/5 of a foot more per minute than Object 2.

D.Choice: Object 1 travels 5/6 of a foot more per minute than Object 2.

SubTopics: For an event described in everyday language, identify the outcomes in the sample space which compose the event, when the sample space is represented using organized lists, tables, and tree diagrams.
Content: Jamal, Gary, Charlie, and Brian are going to stand in a line, one behind the other. In how many different ways can they stand in the line?

SubTopics: Construct equations to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.
Content: What is the value of y when –5 = (y – 7)/9?

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving numerical expressions with rational numbers using the four operations.
Content: Which choice has a value that is closest to the value of the following expression?

SubTopics: Understand that a proportion is a relationship of equality between ratios.
Content: The equation y = 6.75x models the cost, in dollars, to purchase x pounds of steak at grocery store 1. This table shows the cost to buy different weights of steak at grocery store 2.
problems/NC18G7M/media/40a.jpg
Which statement is true?

A.Choice: The cost of steak at grocery store 1 is $0.75 less per pound than at grocery store 2.

B.Choice: The cost of steak at grocery store 1 is $0.75 more per pound than at grocery store 2.

C.Choice: The cost of steak at grocery store 1 is $0.50 less per pound than at grocery store 2.

D.Choice: The cost of steak at grocery store 1 is $0.50 more per pound than at grocery store 2.

SubTopics: Use measures of center and measures of variability for numerical data from random samples to draw comparative inferences about two populations.
Content: This table shows the number of points two teams scored in five games.
problems/NC18G7M/media/41a.jpg
What is the difference in the mean absolute deviation of the two teams?

SubTopics: Solve multi-step real-world and mathematical problems posed with rational numbers in algebraic expressions.
Content: Daniel earned $8.00 per hour at his job.

:ibox:• Daniel works 35 hours each week.
• He received a 5% pay increase.
How much more money will Daniel earn each week after the pay increase?

SubTopics: Calculate the measure of variability of a data set and understand that it describes how the values of the data set vary with a single number.
Content: The test scores for the students in Mr. Miller's math class are shown here.
What is the range of the test scores?

SubTopics: Solve real-world and mathematical problems.
Content: The two ends of this triangular right prism are equilateral triangles. The measurements are given to the nearest tenth of a cm.
problems/NC18G7M/media/44a.jpg
What is the surface area of the prism?

SubTopics: Develop a uniform probability model by assigning equal probability to all outcomes, and use the model to determine probabilities of events.
Content: The probability that a person in a certain town has brown eyes is 2 out of 5. A survey of 450 people from that same town was taken. How many people would be expected to have brown eyes?
